'''Attractiveness''' or '''attraction''' is a quality that causes an interest, desire in, or gravitation to something or someone.<ref name="cognitive_emotions_1989">{{cite book|last=Ortony|first=Andrew|author2=Gerald L. Clore |author3=Allan Collins |title=The Cognitive Structure of Emotions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dA3JEEAp6TsC&pg=PA68&dq=attraction+emotion&sig=8QSeZbpsC_EjRjrpl-_InGsQHvY#PPA59,M1|year=1989|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-38664-0|page=59 |doi=10.2307/2074241}}</ref>{{rp|59}}<ref name="Review_Ortony_1989">{{cite journal |title=Review of 'The Cognitive Structure of Emotions' by Andrew Ortony, Gerald L. Clore and Allan Collins |first=B. N. |last=Colby |journal=Contemporary Sociology |volume=18 |number=6 |date=November 1989 |pages=957‚Äì958 |publisher=[[American Sociological Association]] |jstor=2074241 |access-date=}}</ref><ref group="Notes">Their often-cited 1988 publication provided a "general theory of how psychological situations elicit emotions and make them intense. Its [http://people.virginia.edu/~gc4q/index.php/people/48-gerald-l-clore.html chief application] is in computer science as the emotion engine of intelligent agents in computer games, and interactive training modules." Anthony Ortony, professor at Northwestern University with a focus on Psychology, Education, and Computer Science; Gerald L. Clore is a Psychology Professor at the University of Virginia with a focus on emotion and its cognitive consequences; and Allan Collins is professor of Learning Sciences specializing in Education, Psychology, and Artificial Intelligence at Northwestern University.</ref><ref group="Notes">In ''The Cognitive Structure of Emotions'' Ortony, Clore and Collins describe the intensity of joy emotions; praiseworthiness affects the intensity of pride emotions, and appealingness affects the intensity of the object-based attraction emotions. The "perception of charm and physical beauty" through their influence on "appealingness" only have an indirect effect on the intensity of attraction emotions.</ref> ''Attraction'' may also refer to the object of the attraction itself, as in ''[[tourist attraction]]''.
==Visual attractiveness== Visual attractiveness or visual appeal is attraction produced primarily by [[visual perception|visual stimuli]].
==Physical attractiveness== {{Main|Physical attractiveness}}
[[Physical attractiveness]] is the perception of the physical traits of an individual [[human]] [[person]] as pleasing or [[beauty|beautiful]]. It can include various implications, such as [[sexual attractiveness]], [[cuteness]], [[Interpersonal attraction#Similarity (like-attracts-like)|similarity]] and [[physical attractiveness|physique]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
Physical attractiveness can also include the attraction of smell. Pheromones secreted by animals and humans alike can attract others, and this is viewed as being attracted to smell.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/02/14/science-of-attraction-_n_6661522.html|title=The Strange Science Of Sexual Attraction|last=Gregoire|first=Carolyn|date=2015-02-14|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-US}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=HuffPo isn't the best possible source for medicine related topics|date=June 2018}} [[Human sex pheromones]] may play a role in human attraction, although it is unclear how well humans can actually pick up on the pheromones of another.
Judgment of attractiveness of physical traits is partly universal to all human cultures, partly dependent on culture or [[society]] or time period, partly biological, and partly subjective and individual.<ref>{{cite web | last = H√∂nekopp | first = Johannes | authorlink = | title = Once more: Is beauty in the eye of the beholder? Relative contributions of private and shared taste to judgments of facial attractiveness | publisher = APA| year = 2006 | url = http://www.tu-chemnitz.de/hsw/psychologie/professuren/allpsy2/Artikel/JEPHPP_2006.pdf}}</ref><ref name="cognitive_emotions_1989"/><ref name="Review_Ortony_1989"/>
==The Science Behind Attraction== According to a study determining the golden ratio for facial beauty, the most attractive face is one with average distances between facial features, and an average length and width of the face itself.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pallett|first=Pamela|last2=Link|first2=Stephen|last3=Lee|first3=Kang|date=November 6, 2009|title=New "Golden" Ratios for Facial Beauty|pmc=2814183|journal=Vision Research|volume=50|pages=149‚Äì154|via=}}</ref>. Facial attractiveness, or [[beauty]], can also be determined by symmetry. If a face is asymmetrical, this can indicate unhealthy genetic information. Therefore, if a face is symmetrical (see [[Facial symmetry]]), healthy genetic information is implied. People will judge potential mates based off the physical expression of the genetic health, which is their apparent attractiveness<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=B.C.|last2=Little|first2=A.C.|last3=Penton-Voak|first3=I.S.|last4=Tiddeman|first4=B.P.|last5=Burt|first5=D.M.|last6=Perrett|first6=D.I.|date=November 2001|title=Facial symmetry and judgements of apparent health: Support for a ‚Äúgood genes‚Äù explanation of the attractiveness‚Äìsymmetry relationship|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1090513801000836|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=22|pages=417-420|via=}}</ref>. This supports the good genes theory, which indicates that attractiveness is seen as a way to ensure that offspring will have the healthiest genes and therefore the best chance of survival. Certain trains that indicate good genes (such as clear skin or facial symmetry) are seen as desirable when choosing a partner<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/good-genes-hypothesis|title=Good genes hypothesis|last=The Editors of Encyclopedia Britannica|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia Brittanica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 June 2018}}</ref>.
==Sexual Selection and Attraction in Non-human Animals==
Among animals, females often are "choosy" about who they pick for a mate. They will look for characteristics in their potential mates that ensure their offspring will have healthy genetic material. Therefore, they will be attracted to certain traits or behaviors of their potential mates. Attraction among animals is based mostly on what will give the females the best chance of having the most and healthiest offspring that will likely survive to adulthood because of the traits they will inherit from the male<ref> Alcock, J. (2001). The Evolution of Reproductive Behavior. In Animal Behavior. (7 ed. pp. 341) Sunderland, Massachusetts: Arizona State University. </ref>. Females will look for signs of health in the males, such as large and fancy adornments, bright colors, or other features that the male will only have if he is in good health. <ref>Bateson, P. Editor. (1983). Sexual Selection by Female Choice by Peter O'Donald. in Mate Choice. (pp. 53). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.</ref>.
==Eye candy (slang for visual appeal)== Eye candy is a slang term for superficial attractiveness.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/marathi/features/the-english-we-speak/ep-151103 |title=The English We Speak |date=November 3, 2015 |work=BBC |accessdate=September 27, 2017}}</ref> In a 2017 ''[[Boston Globe]]'' article about the potential for [[cheerleading]] at the Olympics, eye candy was used to describe cheerleaders as "entertainment popularized by professional sports in the United States."<ref>{{cite news |title=Is cheerleading coming to the Olympics? |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/2017/02/18/cheerleading-coming-olympics/13A4niz8VlbbE6O9enqYqO/story.html |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=February 18, 2017 |access-date=September 27, 2017 |first=Shira |last=Springer}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/columnists/ct-ryan-ending-nfl-cheerleaders-spt-0107-20160107-column.html |title=Time for NFL to end use of cheerleaders |date=January 7, 2016 |access-date=September 27, 2017|first=Shannon |last=Ryan |newspaper=Chicago Tribune}}</ref> The term has also been used in professional sports in the United States referring to female athletes.<ref>{{cite news |title=It's Time For Sports Broadcasting To Stop Relegating Women to Sideline Eye Candy |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/annedoyle/2013/01/21/its-time-for-sports-broadcasting-to-stop-relegating-women-to-sideline-eye-candy/#4d6ef74e3fc9 |work=Forbes |date=January 21, 2017 |access-date=September 27, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Interpersonal attraction]] *[[Interest (emotion)]] *[https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Animal_Behavior/Sexual_Selection_and_Mate_Choice_by_Females Animal Behavior/Sexual Selection and Mate Choice by Females]

[[File:Regenerative Reliquary by Amy Karle 2016 01.jpg|alt="REGENERATIVE RELIQUARY" by Amy Karle, 2016 bioart sculpture of hand design 3D printed |thumb|BioArt Sculpture "Regenerative Reliquary" by Amy Karle (2016)]] '''BioArt''' is an [[art]] [[practice (social theory)|practice]] where humans work with live tissues, [[Microbial art|bacteria]], living organisms, and life processes. Using scientific processes such as [[biotechnology]] (including technologies such as [[genetic engineering]], [[tissue culture]], and [[cloning]]) the artworks are produced in laboratories, galleries, or [[artist]]s' [[studio]]s. The scope of BioArt is considered by some artists to be strictly limited to "living forms", while other artists would include art that uses the imagery of contemporary medicine and biological research, or require that it address a controversy or blind spot posed by the very character of the life sciences.<ref>{{cite book |last=Pentecost | first=Claire |editor-first=da Costa| editor-last=Beatrice |title=Tactical Biopolitics: Art, Activism and Technoscience |publisher=The MIT Press |pages=110 |chapter=Outfitting the Laboratory of the Symbolic: Toward a Critical Inventory of Bioart |isbn=978-0-262-04249-9| year=2008 }}</ref>
Although BioArtists work with living matter, there is some debate as to the stages at which matter can be considered to be alive or living. Creating living beings and practicing in the life sciences brings about [[ethical]], [[social]], and [[aesthetic]] inquiry. The phrase "BioArt" was coined by [[Eduardo Kac]] in 1997 in relation to his artwork ''Time Capsule''. Although it originated at the end of the 20th century, through the works of pioneers like [[Joe Davis (artist)|Joe Davis]], [http://www.martademenezes.com Marta de Menezes] and the artists hosted by [[Symbiotica]], BioArt is more widely practiced now.
==Overview== [[File:Self Portre Yin - Yang (BioArt).tif|thumb|Self Portre 1988 Yin - Yang (BioArt), playing on the parallels between image manipulation and cloning]]
BioArt is often intended to be shocking or humorous.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=February 2017}} One survey of the field, ''Isotope: A Journal of Literary Science and Nature Writing'', puts it this way: "BioArt is often ludicrous. It can be lumpy, gross, unsanitary, sometimes invisible, and tricky to keep still on the auction block. But at the same time, it does something very traditional that art is supposed to do: draw attention to the beautiful and grotesque details of nature that we might otherwise never see."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110212142541/http://www.emilyvoigt.com/isotope.html#content The Art is Alive<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
While raising questions about the role of science in society, "most of these works tend toward social reflection, conveying political and societal criticism through the combination of artistic and scientific processes."<ref name="auto">{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/ethics/2007-03-05-bio-art_N.htm?csp=34 | work=USA Today | first=Jessica M. | last=Pasko | title=Bio-artists use science to create art | date=2007-03-05}}</ref>
While most people who practice BioArt are categorized as artists in this new media, they can also be seen as scientists, since the actual medium within a work pertains to molecular structures, and so forth. Because of this dual-acceptance, the Department of Cell Biology at Harvard University invites anyone to submit works based on scientific or artistic value.<ref>[http://bioart.med.harvard.edu/bioart_introduction.html BIOart] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020121935/http://bioart.med.harvard.edu/bioart_introduction.html |date=October 20, 2008 }}</ref> This can encourage anyone to submit work they strongly respond to.
==Exposing artists to laboratories== The laboratory work can pose a challenge to the artist, at first, as the environment is often foreign to the artist. While some artists have prior scientific training, others must be trained to perform the procedures or work in tandem with scientists who can perform the tasks that are required. Bio artists often use formations relating to or engaged with science and scientific practices, such as working with bacteria or live-tissue.
Much of the art involves tissue-culturing and transgenics, a term for a variety of genetic engineering processes through which genetic material from one organism is altered by the addition of synthesized or transplanted genetic material from another organism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17387568/|title=Bio-artists bridge gap between arts, sciences|date=4 March 2007|publisher=MSNBC}}</ref>
In 2000, Eduardo Kac commissioned the creation of a transgenic [[Green fluorescent protein|GFP]] bunny as part of a piece called GFP Bunny. "The PR campaign included a picture of Kac holding a white rabbit and another, iconic image of a rabbit photographically enhanced to appear green."<ref>{{cite book |last=Pentecost | first=Claire |editor-first=da Costa| editor-last=Beatrice |title=Tactical Biopolitics: Art, Activism and Technoscience |publisher=The MIT Press |pages=107 |chapter=Outfitting the Laboratory of the Symbolic: Toward a Critical Inventory of Bioart |isbn=978-0-262-04249-9| year=2008 }}</ref>
The Tissue Culture & Art Project in collaboration with [[Stelarc]] grew a 1/4 scale replica of an ear using human cells. The project was carried out at [[Symbiotica]]: the Art & Science Collaborative Research Laboratory, School of Anatomy and Human Biology, [[University of Western Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tca.uwa.edu.au/extra/extra_ear.html|title=Extra Ear ¬º Scale - The Tissue Culture & Art Project in Collaboration with Stelarc|publisher=}}</ref>
==Art addressing topics in biology and society== [[File:FPbeachTsien.jpg|thumb|It is debated whether BioArt must, like this work of [[microbial art]], be made with actual organisms. Artwork made with bacteria expressing 8 different colors of [[green fluorescent protein|fluorescent proteins]]]]
The scope of the term BioArt is a subject of ongoing debate. The primary point of debate centers around whether BioArt must necessarily involve manipulation of biological material, as is the case in [[microbial art]] which by definition is made of [[microorganism|microbes]]. A broader definition of the term would include work that addresses the social and ethical considerations of the biological sciences.<ref>See Bio Art entry in Oxford Art Online, Oxford University Press, 2007-2014. {{subscription required}}</ref> Under these terms BioArt as a genre has many crossovers with fields such as critical or speculative design.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Anker |first1=Suzanne |title=The beginnings and the ends of Bio Art |url=http://www.suzanneanker.com/wp-content/uploads/2014-The-beginnings-and-the-ends-of-Bio-Art-Bio-Art-Life-in-the-Anthropocene-Artlink-Magazine.pdf |journal=Artlink |date=2014 |volume=34 |issue=3 |pages=}}</ref> This type of work often reaches a much broader general audience, and is focused on starting discussions in this space, rather than pioneering or even using specific biological practices. Examples in this space include Ray Fish shoes, which advertised shoes made and patterned with genetically engineered stingray skin,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextnature.net/2012/12/the-rise-and-fall-or-rayfish-footwear/|title=The Rise and Fall or Rayfish Footwear - Next Nature Network|date=19 December 2012|publisher=}}</ref> and BiteLabs, a biotech startup that attempted to make salami out of meat cultured from celebrity tissue samples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/the-guy-who-want-to-sell-you-salami-made-out-of-james-franco-are-100-serious |title=The Guy Who Wants to Sell Lab-Grown Salami Made of Kanye West Is "100% Serious" |publisher=|date=2014-02-26 }}</ref>
==Controversy== BioArt has been scrutinized for its apparent lack of ethics. ''[[USA Today]]'' reported that animal rights groups accused Kac and others of using animals unfairly for their own personal gain, and conservative groups question the use of transgenic technologies and tissue-culturing from a moral standpoint.<ref name="auto"/>
Alka Chandna, a senior researcher with [[PETA]] in Norfolk, Virginia, has stated that using animals for the sake of art is no different from using animal fur for clothing material. "Transgenic manipulation of animals is just a continuum of using animals for human end, regardless of whether it is done to make some sort of sociopolitical critique. The suffering and exacerbation of stress on the animals is very problematic."<ref name="auto"/>
However, many BioArt projects deal with the manipulation of cells and not whole organisms, such as ''[[Victimless Leather]]'' by [[Symbiotica]]. "An actualized possibility of wearing 'leather' without killing an animal is offered as a starting point for cultural discussion. Our intention is not to provide yet another consumer product, but rather to raise questions about our exploitation of other living beings."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tca.uwa.edu.au/vl/vl.html|title=Victemless Leather|publisher=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Computer art]] * [[Cyberarts]] * [[Digital art]] * [[Electronic art]] * [[Environmental art]] * [[Evolutionary art]] * [[Internet art]] * [[Neuroaesthetics]] * [[New Media art]] * [[Hybrid arts]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Color symbolism''' in [[art]] and [[anthropology]] refers to the use of color as a [[symbol]] in various [[Culture|cultures]]. There is great diversity in the use of colors and their associations between cultures<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Smith|first=N.S. |last2=Whitfield|first2=T.W.A. |last3=Wiltshire|first3=T.J. |date=April 1990 |title=The accuracy of the NCS, DIN, and OSA-UCS colour atlases |journal=Color Research & Application |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=111‚Äì116 |doi=10.1002/col.5080150209 |issn=0361-2317}}</ref> and even within the same culture in different time periods.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Color psychology and color therapy: a factual study of the influence of color on human life |last=Birren |first=Faber |date=2006 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=978-1425424107 |location=Whitefish, MT |oclc=74452551}}</ref> The same color may have very different associations within the same culture at any time. Diversity in color symbolism occurs because color meanings and symbolism occur on an individual, cultural and universal basis. Color symbolism is also context-dependent and influenced by changes over time.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Color symbolism |doi=10.5040/9781501303364.ch-014 |title=Color Studies |editor1=Edith Anderson Feisner |editor2=Ronald Reed |edition=3rd |year=2016 |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=New York |isbn=978-1-50130-336-4 |oclc=1053938255 }}</ref> Symbolic representations of religious concepts or articles may include a specific color with which the concept or object is associated.<ref>{{Cite journal |language=de |title=Encyclopaedia Britannica|doi=10.1163/9789004337862_lgbo_com_050367 }}</ref> There is evidence to suggest that colors have been used for this purpose as early as 90,000 BC.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
== Common associations ==
=== Red === Red is often associated with love, passion, and lust. It is frequently used in relation to Valentine's Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=valentine&safe=off&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJobTilr7eAhWCLn0KHaP-BZIQ_AUIFCgC&biw=1366&bih=618 |title=valentine - Google Search|website=www.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It can also be used to signify danger or warning. For instance, it is used for stop signs<ref>{{Citation|title=Road vertical signs. Variable message traffic signs|publisher=BSI British Standards|doi=10.3403/03263875u}}</ref> and fire engines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocklandfirefighters.org/?zone=/unionactive/view_article.cfm&HomeID=50076&page=Fire20Department20Traditions|title=Why are fire trucks red?|website=www.rocklandfirefighters.org|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> In China, red is often used to symbolize good luck or happiness, and is used for many holidays or weddings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/color-symbolism-in-chinese-culture-what-do-traditional-chinese-colors-mean/|title=Color Symbolism in Chinese Culture: What do Traditional Chinese Colors Mean?|date=2015-01-16|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Blue === Blue is the color of the ocean and the sky; it often symbolizes serenity, stability, or inspiration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-blue/|title=Meaning of The Color Blue {{!}}|last=|first=|date=2011-01-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> It can be a calming color, and symbolize reliability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/blue-color-meaning-the-color-blue/|title=Blue Color Meaning - The Color Blue|last=|first=|date=2013-03-01|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> In the Catholic Church, the Virgin Mary is most often depicted wearing blue, to symbolize her divinity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aleteia.org/2017/06/24/why-is-the-blessed-virgin-mary-always-wearing-blue/|title=Why is the Blessed Virgin Mary always wearing blue?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-24|work=Aleteia ‚Äî Catholic Spirituality, Lifestyle, World News, and Culture|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Blue is widely used for baby boys' clothes or bedrooms, although the reason blue is so strongly associated with boys is debated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/22037-pink-girls-blue-boys.html|title=Why Is Pink for Girls and Blue for Boys?|date=1 August 2012|first=Natalie|last=Wolchover|work=Live Science|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Yellow === Yellow is a color often associated with sunshine or joy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colormatters.com/the-meanings-of-colors/yellow|title=Yellow|last=Morton|first=Jill|website=www.colormatters.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It is sometimes used in association with cowardice or fear, i.e, the phrase "yellow-bellied".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/yellow-bellied|title=yellow-bellied - Dictionary Definition|work=Vocabulary.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Children tend to like this color, and it is used to market products to children;<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-yellow/|title=Meaning of The Color Yellow {{!}}|date=2011-02-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> it is also used for school buses and taxi cabs since it is such a bright, noticeable color.<ref name=":0" />
=== Green === Green is most often used to represent nature, healing, or fertility, since it's such a dominant color in nature. It can be a very relaxing color<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-green/|title=Meaning of The Color Green {{!}}|date=2011-01-25|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> but is also used in the US to symbolize money, greed, or jealousy.<ref name=":1" /> Saying that someone is "green" means they're inexperienced or new.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/green|title=Green definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
=== Black === Black, in Western culture, is considered a negative color and usually symbolizes death, grief, or evil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorpsychology.org/black/|title=Black Color Psychology - Black Meaning & Personality|work=Color Psychology|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> People often wear black for mourning, although this practice isn't as wide-spread as it was in the past.<ref>{{Citation|last=Jalland|first=Pat|date=1996-11-07|pages=77‚Äì97|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198201885|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198201885.003.0005|title=Death in the Victorian Family|chapter=Death and the Victorian Doctors}}</ref>
=== White === White most often symbolizes perfection, faith, innocence, softness, and cleanliness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-white/|title=Meaning of The Color White {{!}}|date=2010-12-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Brides often wear white dresses to symbolize virginity or purity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridesmagazine.co.uk/article/why-do-brides-wear-white|title=Why Do Brides Wear White? And Other Questions|last=Davis|first=Lexxi|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
=== Pink === Pink is associated with softness, femininity, sweetness, and love.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-pink/|title=Meaning of The Color Pink {{!}}|date=2010-11-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> However, it was formerly used as a masculine color, frequently used for baby boys; it wasn't until the early 20th century that the gender roles of pink and blue were reversed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/health/colorscope-pink-boy-girl-gender/index.html|title=The complicated gender history of pink|last=Ant|first=Puja Bhattacharjee, CNN Animation by Giant|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
==Color symbolism in marketing== Color plays an important role in setting expectations for a product and communicating its key characteristics.<ref name=Asiam>{{Cite journal |last=Aslam |first=Mubeen M. |date=2006 |title=Are You Selling the Right Colour? A Cross‚ÄêCultural Review of Colour as a Marketing Cue |journal=Journal of Marketing Communications |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=15‚Äì30 |doi=10.1080/13527260500247827}}</ref> Color is the second most important element that allows consumers to identify brand packaging.<ref name=Popa>{{Cite journal|last=Popa|first=C.N. |last2=Popescu|first2=S. |last3=Berehoiu|first3=R.M.T. |last4=Berehoiu|first4=S.M.T. |date=2013 |title=Considerations regarding use and role of colour in marketing |url=http://managementjournal.usamv.ro/pdf/vol.XIII/Art44.pdf |journal= Scientific Papers Series - Management, Economic Engineering in Agriculture and Rural Development |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=269‚Äì274}}</ref>
Marketers for products with an international market navigate the color symbolism variances between cultures with targeted advertising. The car manufacturer, Volkswagen ran a commercial in Italy with a black sheep in the middle of a larger flock symbolizing those who owned a VW Golf as someone unique and self-assured among a crowd of others who were not. In several cultures around the world, a black sheep represents an outcast and is seen as something undesirable. In Italy, a black sheep represents confidence and independence.[[File:Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017.jpg|thumb|Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017]] There are many additional variances in color symbolism between cultures. Cold is symbolized by blue in East Asia, the USA, and Sweden while warmth is symbolized by yellow in the USA and by blue in The Netherlands. Sometimes the meanings of colors are in stark opposition across geographic boundaries, requiring products marketed to specific demographics to account for those changes across different markets. For instance, feminity is symbolized by blue in The Netherlands and pink in the USA., whereas masculinity is symbolized by blue in Sweden and the USA, and red in the UK and France.<ref name=Asiam/> In some instances color symbolism in marketing is constructed. For companies whose products are defined by the name of their color their sales are susceptible to the symbolism and association of that name. In one example, a company selling a paint color named ‚Äúoff white‚Äù more than doubled its sales by renaming the same color as ‚Äúancient silk.‚Äù<ref name=Popa/>
==Conceptualizations of colors cross-culturally== Color symbolism has morphed over time. Between the 5th and 17th centuries color was largely related to in a religious context. Blue was symbolic of heaven and white of purity. Today, purity is still symbolized by white in Australia and the USA but by blue in other countries like India. Similarly, the church influenced the perception of colors like crimson and purple. Largely because the dyes for these colors could only be sourced from precious pigments, religious figures like Madonna, Cardinals, and the Virgin were seen in scarlet and purple. [[File:Vatican II - Dubois - Li√©nart.JPG|thumb|Vatican II - Dubois - Li√©nart]]Today, purple symbolizes evil and infidelity in Japan, but the same is symbolized by blue in East Asia and by yellow in France. Additionally, the sacred color of Hindu and Buddhist monks is orange. [[File:Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap.jpg|thumb|Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap]] The Renaissance was also a time in which black and purple were colors of mourning. Today, Mourning or death is symbolized by white in East Asia, black in the USA, and blue in Iran, while happiness is symbolized by white in Australia and NZ, and yellow in China.<ref name=Asiam/>
There is a general disagreement over whether reactions to color and their symbolism are a result of cultural conditioning or of instinct. Several studies concluded that color is part of the social learning process because of the significant symbolism within the culture. High quality, trustworthiness and dependability are symbolized by blue in the USA, Japan, Korea and green and yellow in China - as well as purple in China, South Korea and Japan. Because of these variances, critical cues vary across cultures. Warning signs are coded differently as danger is symbolized by green in Malaysia, and red in the USA and Mexico. The same color of green symbolizes envy in Belgium and the USA, but envy is symbolized by yellow in Germany and Russia, and purple in Mexico. Even the colors that denote powerful emotions vary. Love is symbolized by green in Japan, red and purple in China, Korea, Japan and the USA. Unluckiness is symbolized by red in Chad, Nigeria and Germany. Luckiness is symbolized by red in China, Denmark and Argentina. The traditional bridal color is red in China and white in the USA. Ambition and desire are symbolized by red in India.<ref name=Asiam/>
== Color symbolism in Arabic culture == Color has different meanings in different countries.¬† We can specifically look at the Arabic culture and take it into consideration. We can start with the color white. In the Arabic culture, white is thought of as the color that is symbolic for nature.¬† Since it related with nature, it has a meaning that is one of positivity. It also relates with that of being clean and pure.¬† White is a color that is commonly worn during prayers and with that, it symbolizes purity. White‚Äôs positive connotation carries out into other aspects.¬† It is also used as a symbol for positivity in the future. White is also used to symbolize the end of war. You will also see women adorn white at their weddings as a sign of positivity.¬† Since doves are white, they share the symbolic meaning that comes with the color.¬† This in turn causes them to be associated with positivity of good news.
When you look at the color Black in Arabic culture you can find that it is related to funerals and death. Women will often wear black to funerals in order to show that they are sad for those who have passed. ¬†Also relating to death, black is associated with hell. Black is also used to symbolize dark.¬† Hell is thought to be a dark black place associating black as negative. ¬†Black in general is looked at as having negative connotations around it. For example, the symbolism of a black heart refers to someone who is unkind.¬† [[File:Red rose with black background.jpg|thumb]] Green is a color that is commonly found in Islam.¬† It is a color found in nature and with this, it is associated with and represents goodness. Green is a color that has an overall positive meaning. ¬† The color green also has to do with truthfulness, again going with positivity.¬† If you look at phrases, the symbolic meanings are generally positive.¬† If you look at the phrase green hand, it relates to being generous which is a positive thing.
Red has an overall positive association with it. Often you will find that red is a color associated with roses and blood.¬† The color red has to do with love and passion.¬† In sayings you can find it to have either a negative or positive meaning such as the term red eye relates with anger.¬† The Arabic culture also associates this color with death.
Blue is related with positivity when discussing it with nature, otherwise it can be related with negative connotations. When used in the phrase blue eyes, it refers to jealousy. A blue body relates with death and therefore is associated with negativity.
Yellow is another color that is also associated with nature and the sun.¬† Again, since it is a color related with nature, it takes on the symbolic meaning of positivity.¬† Gold is also categorized under here and is also takes on a positive meaning. ¬†Generally, when used in phrases, the color yellow has to do with negativity.¬† For example, a yellow smile means to be mean.
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasan|first=Amna|date=2011|title=How Colours are Semantically Construed in the Arabic and English Culture: A Comparative study|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1080712.pdf|journal=English Language Teaching|volume=4|pages=206‚Äì213|via=}}</ref> ==Colors and emotions== [[File:Emotions - 3.png|thumb]] Color symbolism is displayed in many ways. One of the most common ways we see color symbolism displayed in through our emotions. In this article Color-emotions associations: Past experience and personal preference it takes a look at how we connect colors with our emotions and how it depends on a person‚Äôs preference and or their past experiences. This article first starts out by talking about the different colors and what they are associated with. The first color it talks about is the color blue and how people see blue as comfort and security and how they see orange as being upsetting. The next one they talk about is yellow which is more of a happy color compared to purple which they say is dignified but I have never heard of purple being seen that way. The next one this article talks about which I find very interesting is the color red. People view the color red in two different ways, one being as a strong and passionate color. However, it is also seen in a very different way, people see it as an aggressive color because it is the color of blood. The last color this article talks about is the color green and how just like red it has two different views. Green can be viewed positively as in quietness but can also be viewed negatively as in guilt. This study took a look at how we associate colors with emotions. This study was done and showed that we associated lighter colors such as blue or yellow with more positive emotions. It then showed how we associated darker colors such as grey or black with more native emotions. However, something very interesting that this study did find is that most young prefer the color black over many other colors. The study was done with college aged students to see how they associate their emotions with colors. Many tests were done such as matching tasks and matching color tests to see what colors they associate with their emotions. The study had 44 men and 54 women in it and they again were all college students. They identified a color sample with one emotion only and it showed what emotional response is connected to a color. The results from this study did find that people mostly associate the color green with being the most positive. Over 95% off people said that green s the most positive because it makes them feel relaxed and then comfortable and at peace. It also showed that people saw yellow as the more excited and energetic emotion, with over 90% agreeing with this. 79% of students found that blue was a calming color because it reminded them of the ocean which is known as a calming place. People did have different answers when it came to red because like explained earlier, red is seen in two very different ways, It has been seen as love by many but also as evil because it remind people of blood. Many people did not seem to like the color purple very much as it was not favored by many for their preferences. The color black was seen to be more negative emotions like fear and depression. Overall, this article shows how color can be important because it is how people associate their emotions and things based on color symbolism.<ref>Kaya & H., Naz & Helen. Color-emotion association: Past experience and personal preference. The University of Georgia, Department of Textiles, Merchandising, and Interiors, 2004.</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://books.google.com/?id=lCoAb9RDVIYC&pg=PA31&dq=color+symbolism+#v=onepage&q=color%20symbolism&f=false | title=AIC 2004 Color and Paints, Interim Meeting of the International Color Association, Proceedings}}</ref>

{{Further|Robert Rauschenberg}} [[File:Bj√∏rn Krogstad Buksa mi.jpg|thumb|The artwork ''Buksa mi'' (My pants) by the Norwegian artist [[Bj√∏rn Krogstad]], from 1968, an example of combine painting]] A '''combine painting''' is an artwork that incorporates various objects into a painted canvas surface, creating a sort of hybrid between [[painting]] and [[sculpture]].<ref>Artspeak, Robert Atkins, 1990</ref><ref name="tws08jan001">{{cite news |author= John Perreault |title= Rauschenberg's combines |quote= If you have never seen Robert Rauschenberg's iconic Bed (1955), Canyon (1959), or the free-standing Monogram (1955-59),... |publisher= Artopia |date= January 6, 2006 |url= http://www.artsjournal.com/artopia/2006/01/rauschenbergs_combines.html |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref><ref name="tws08jan010">{{cite news |title= Art: The Emperor's Combine |quote= Rauschenberg calls his works "combines' because they combine painting with props pasted or fastened to the picture ... |publisher= ''Time Magazine' |date= Apr 18, 1960 |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,874070,00.html |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> Items attached to paintings might include photographic images, clothing, newspaper clippings, [[ephemera]] or any number of [[Dimension|three-dimensional]] objects. The term is most closely associated with the artwork of American artist [[Robert Rauschenberg]] (1925‚Äì2008) who coined the phrase<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/25/arts/design/adding-rauschenberg-and-richter-at-moma.html?_r=0 ''New York Times'' October 24 2013 "‚ÄúWe are fortunate to have six Combines from the mid-‚Äô50s through 1961,‚Äù Ms. Temkin said, referring to the term Rauschenberg coined to describe works that incorporate castoff objects like tires, flatware or furniture."]</ref> to describe his own creations. Rauschenberg‚Äôs Combines explored the blurry boundaries between art and the everyday world. In addition, his cross-medium creations challenged the doctrine of [[medium specificity]] mentioned by modernist art critic [[Clement Greenberg]]. [[Frank Stella]] created a large body of paintings that recall the combine paintings of [[Robert Rauschenberg]] by juxtaposing a wide variety of surface and material in each work ultimately leading to Stella's sculpture and architecture of the 21st century.<ref>[http://www.haberarts.com/schwitt.htm Unhappy Medium, Frank Stella and Kurt Schwitters by John Haber]. Retrieved January 10, 2010.</ref>
==Rauschenberg==
Rauschenberg and his artist friend/flatmate [[Jasper Johns]] used to design window displays together for upscale retailers such as [[Tiffany's]] and [[Bonwit Teller]] in [[New York, New York|Manhattan]] before they became better established as artists.<ref name=tws08jan009/> They shared ideas about art as well as career strategies.<ref name="tws08jan009">{{cite news |author= Adrian Searle |title= Stuff happens: His work is packed with jokes, ideas - and farmyard animals. |quote= What Rauschenberg came to call his Combine paintings are the core of his art, ... |publisher= The Guardian |date= 28 November 2006 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2006/nov/28/art1 |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> Paul Schimmel of the [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles|Museum of Contemporary Art]] described Rauschenberg's ''Combine paintings'' as "some of the most influential, poetic and revolutionary works in the history of American art."<ref name=tws08jan009/> But they've also been called "ramshackle hybrids between painting and sculpture, stage prop and three-dimensional scrap-book assemblage" according to ''The Guardian''{{'}}s critic Adrian Searle.<ref name=tws08jan009/> Searle believed the "different elements of the Combines have been described as having no more relation than the different stories that vie for attention on a newspaper page."<ref name=tws08jan009/> Jasper Johns, as well, used similar techniques; in at least one painting, Johns attached a paintbrush right inside his painting.
Examples of Rauschenberg's ''Combine paintings'' include ''Bed'' (1955), ''Canyon'' (1959), and the free-standing ''[[Monogram (artwork)|Monogram]]'' (1955‚Äì1959).<ref name=tws08jan001/> Rauschenberg's works mostly incorporated [[two-dimensional]] materials held together with "splashes and drips of paint" with occasional 3-D objects.<ref name=tws08jan001/> Critic John Perreault wrote "The Combines are both painting and sculpture‚Äìor, some purists would say, neither."<ref name=tws08jan001/> Perreault liked them since they were memorable, photogenic, and could "stick in the mind" as well as "surprise and keep on surprising."<ref name=tws08jan001/> Rauschenberg added stuffed birds on his 1955 work ''Satellite'', which featured a stuffed pheasant "patrolling its top edge."<ref name=tws08jan011/> In another work, he added a ladder. His Combine ''Broadcast'', featuring three radios blaring at once,<ref name=tws08jan010/> was a "melange of paint, grids, newspaper clips and fabric snippets."<ref name="tws08jan012">{{cite news |author= Grace glueck |title= ART REVIEW; A Collector's Collector Whose Works Went Pop |quote= ...''Broadcast.'' A carefully composed melange of paint, grids, newspaper clips and fabric snippets, it has fastened to its back a real radio, whose knobs are visible on the painting's surface. |publisher= The New York Times |date= May 4, 2001 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/04/arts/art-review-a-collector-s-collector-whose-works-went-pop.html?pagewanted=1 |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> According to one source, his ''Broadcast'' had three radios playing simultaneously, which produced a sort of irritating static, so that one of the work's owners, at one point, replaced the "noise" with tapes of actual programs when guests visited.<ref name=tws08jan012/> Rauschenberg's ''Bed'' had a pillow attached to a patchwork quilt with paint splashed over it.<ref name=tws08jan010/> The idea was to promote immediacy.<ref name=tws08jan010/>
The prevailing theme of Rauschenberg's "combine" paintings is ''"nonmeaning, the absurd, or antiart."'' In this regard the combine paintings relate to [[Pop art]] and their much earlier predecessor [[Dada]].<ref>Varieties of Visual Experience, Edmund Burke Feldman, Harry N. Abrams, Inc.; 3rd edition (March 1987), {{ISBN|978-0-8109-1735-4}}</ref>
==Exponential increase in value== In the early 1960s, Rauschenberg's Combines sold from $400 to $7,500.<ref name=tws08jan010/> But their value shot upwards. In 1999, the [[Museum of Modern Art]], which had balked at buying Rauschenberg's work decades earlier, spent $12 million to buy his ''Factum II'' which the artist made in 1957.<ref name="tws08jan002">{{cite news |author= Kelly Devine Thomas |title= Tracking the highest prices paid for contemporary artworks |quote= ...New York‚Äôs Museum of Modern Art spent around $12 million in 1999 for Rauschenberg‚Äôs combine painting Factum II (1957) |publisher= ARTNews |date= May 2004 |url= http://www.artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=1520 |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> Rauschenberg's ''Rebus'' was valued in 1991 at $7.3 million.<ref name=tws08jan007/> A three-panel work created in 1955 that takes its name from the Latin for a "puzzle of images and words",<ref name="tws08jan004">{{cite news |author= Emmanuelle Soichet |title= MoMA Acquires Rebus, A Key Early Work by Rauschenberg |quote= the Museum of Modern Art announced today that it has bought the three-panel "combine" painting long thought to be a seminal work in the artist's development. |publisher= BLOUINARTINFO |date= January 23, 2007 |url= http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/560/moma-acquires-rebus-a-key-early-work-by-rauschenberg/ |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> it "builds a narrative from seemingly nonsensical sequences of found images and abstract elements," according to ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name=tws08jan011/> MOMA bought ''Rebus'' in 2005.<ref name=tws08jan004/> Rauschenberg reportedly said that the images in ''Rebus'' jostle with each other "like pedestrians on a street."<ref name=tws08jan004/> Rauschenberg's ''Photograph'', a Combine painting from 1959, was valued at $10.7 million by Sotheby's in 2008.<ref name="tws08jan007">{{cite news |author= Judd Tully |title= Art+Auction |quote= $10.7 million, set last May at Sotheby‚Äôs New York by Photograph, a small 1959 ‚ÄúCombine‚Äù painting. |publisher= ARTINFO |date= May 2, 2008 |url= http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/27439/impressionistmodern-and-contemporary-art/?printer_friendly=1 |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> His work ''Bantam'' sold for $2.6 million in 2009.<ref name="tws08jan003">{{cite news |author= Judd Tully |title= New York: Contemporary Art |quote= Robert Rauschenberg‚Äôs little 1955 combine painting Bantam (est. $3-4 million) for $2,602,500 ... |publisher= BLOUINARTINFO |date= January 7, 2009 |url= http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/29771/new-york-contemporary-art/ |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> In 2008, ''The New York Times''{{'}} art critic Roberta Smith, who described Combines as "multimedia hybrids", wrote MOMA was "Rauschenberg Central" because it owned over 300 of his works.<ref name="tws08jan011">{{cite news |author= Roberta Smith |title= Rauschenberg Got a Lot From the City and Left a Lot Behind |quote= In New York, MoMA is Rauschenberg Central. It owns nearly 300 works, many of them prints, and usually has at least a dozen major efforts on view. |publisher= The New York Times |date= May 16, 2008 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/16/arts/design/16raus.html |accessdate= 2010-01-08 }}</ref> The Whitney owned 60 Rauschenbergs.<ref name=tws08jan011/> In 2012, ''Canyon'' was donated to MoMA by the children of Ileana Sonnabend as part of an IRS settlement that valued the work at $65 million.<ref name="tws12nov281">{{cite news |author= Patricia Cohen |title= MoMA Gains Treasure That Met Also Coveted |quote= The I.R.S., however, insisted this masterwork was worth $65 million. It demanded they pay estate taxes of $29.2 million plus another $11.7 million in penalties. |publisher= The New York Times |date= Nov 28, 2012 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/28/arts/design/moma-gains-treasure-that-metropolitan-museum-of-art-also-coveted.html |accessdate= 2012-11-28 }}</ref>
== ''Canyon'' (1959) == [[File:Robert Rauschenberg's 'Canyon', 1959.jpg|alt= Robert Rauschenberg's Canyon combine 1959: oil, pencil, paper, fabric, metal, cardboard box, printed paper, printed reproductions, photograph, wood, paint tube, and mirror on canvas with oil on bald eagle, string, and pillow.|thumb|''Canyon,'' 1959 Combine: oil, pencil, paper, fabric, metal, cardboard box, printed paper, printed reproductions, photograph, wood, paint tube, and mirror on canvas with oil on bald eagle, string, and pillow
Robert Rauschenberg
207.6 √ó 177.8 √ó 61 cm ]] ''Canyon,'' one of Rauschenberg's most recognizable Combines, has been the subject of art historical debate revolving around the validity of reading Rauschenberg's work iconographically. Historian [[Kenneth Bendiner]] famously proposed ''Canyon'' as a playful recreation of a 1635 [[Rembrandt]] painting depicting the abduction of [[The Abduction of Ganymede|Ganymede]], interpreting the suspended pillow as Ganymede's buttocks and the stuffed bald eagle as the form assumed by the Greek god Zeus.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Robert Rauschenberg and the Neo-Avant-Garde|last=Branden|first=Joseph|publisher=MIT Press|year=2002|isbn=|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts, and London|pages=162}}</ref> Other historians and critics, such as [[Joseph Branden]] have argued that searching for iconography in Rauschenberg's Combines is useless because it can be made to exist anywhere.<ref name=":0" /> Bendiner's interpretation is discredited for failing to account for compositional movement and for disregarding a number of elements within the work, for example the blue and red text in the center, in order to mould the interpretation to it.
Interpretations of Rauschenberg's Combines vary from: a deeply personal and subjective collage of expression (often homoerotic), to a surface of indecipherable, or rather infinitely cipher-able, materials which challenge notions of painting, sculpture, reception, and chance, to a multivalent iconographic landscape that seems to resist fixed decoding in favor of a more open-ended play of meaning. Rauschenberg himself states "I don't want a painting to be just an expression of my personality. I feel it ought to be much better than that ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve always felt as though, whatever I‚Äôve used and whatever I‚Äôve done, the method was always closer to a ''collaboration'' with materials than to any kind of conscious manipulation and control."<ref>Rauschenberg quoted in Calvin Tomkins, ‚ÄòProfiles: Moving Out,‚Äô ''The New Yorker'', vol.40, 29 Feb. 1964, p.59.</ref>
[[Moira Roth]] links the Combines to [[Marcel Duchamp|Duchamp's]] indifferent attitude in art, arguing that the perceived density of the content, and the integration of mass media elements is a facade born out of the alienation and indifference experienced by the artist during the [[McCarthyism|McCarthy Period]]. Jonathan Katz argues that underneath the impersonal and inexpressive appearance of his work is a secret homosexual code that can unlock some of the significance of Rauschenberg's work,<ref>Jonathan Katz: ‚ÄòLovers and Divers‚Äô (1998) p.24</ref> but Ed Krƒçma points out the weakness of steering the analysis towards preconceived conclusions, especially since Rauschenberg's work is described as a poetry of infinite possibilities.
More recent interpretations of ''Canyon,'' reconsider the work in [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] terms, claiming that the Combine works more like a human mind than a human eye; Fragmented scraps of images, news cutouts, found objects and paint interact in esoteric ways and more closely resemble a cerebral process than a 'traditional' image. Yve-Alain Bois calls the search for iconographic meaning in Rauschenberg's work misguided because it is too limiting. His art's "lack of center" is a statement in itself, and the infinite permutations of meaning that can result highlight the subjectivity of art reception that postmodernism explores.<ref>Bois, Yve-Alain. "Eye to the Ground." Artforum International. Artforum Inc. March, 2006. p.246-247</ref>
===Additional note===
Under U.S. law, ''Canyon'' can never be sold since it contains a stuffed bald eagle, violating the 1940 [[Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act]] as well as the 1918 [[Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918|Migratory Bird Treaty Act]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2012/05/01/rauschenberg-eagle-ruffles-feathers/|title=Rauschenberg Eagle Ruffles Feathers|last=Kinsella|first=Eileen|date=January 5, 2012|website=Art News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 10, 2018}}</ref>

Beethoven's and Bruckner's copyists --> [[File:Art-students and copyists in the Louvre gallery, Paris.jpg|thumb|270px|Art-students and copyists in the [[Mus√©e du Louvre|Louvre gallery]], [[Paris]], 1868.]]A '''copyist''' is a person who makes copies. The term is sometimes used for artists who make copies of other artists' paintings. However, the modern use of the term is almost entirely confined to music copyists, who are employed by the [[music industry]] to produce neat copies from a [[composer]] or arranger's manuscript.
==Music copyists== Until the 1990s, most copyists worked by hand to write out scores and individual instrumental parts neatly, using a [[calligraphy]] pen, [[manuscript paper]], and often a ruler. Producing parts for an entire [[orchestra]] from a full score was a huge task. In the 1990s, copyists began using [[scorewriter]]s - computer programs which are the music notation equivalent of a [[word processor]]. (Such programs include ''[[Sibelius (computer program)|Sibelius]]'', ''[[Finale (computer program)|Finale]]'', ''[[MuseScore]]'' or ''[[GNU LilyPond]]''). Scorewriters allow the composer or songwriter to "enter" the melodies, rhythms and lyrics to their compositions into the computer using a mouse or by playing the notes on a [[MIDI]]-equipped keyboard. Once a composition is fully entered into a scorewriting program, the computer can be instructed to print out the parts for all of the different instruments.
Both handwritten and computer-based copying require significant understanding of [[musical notation]], [[music theory]], the musical styles and conventions of different styles of music (e.g., regarding appropriate ornamentation, [[harmony]] rules pertaining to [[accidental (music)|accidental]]s, etc.), and strong attention to detail and past conventions. [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] had a contentious relationship with his copyists, who often made mistakes that remained uncorrected until the advent of [[Urtext edition]]s; some [[musicologist]]s have devoted a lot of effort to identifying Beethoven's copyists.<ref>Tyson, Alan (1970). Autumn. "Notes on Five of Beethoven's Copyists" '''23''' 3 ''Journal of the American Musicological Society'' p. 439</ref>

'''Dalle de verre''', from French: "glass slab", is a [[glass art]] technique that uses pieces of coloured glass set in a matrix of [[concrete]] and [[epoxy|epoxy resin]] or other supporting material.
==Technique== The technique was developed by [[Jean Gaudin (glass artist)|Jean Gaudin]] in Paris in the 1930s. Slabs of coloured glass, {{convert|20|cm|inch}} to {{convert|30|cm|inch}} square or rectangular and typically up to {{convert|3|cm|inch}} thick, are shaped by breaking with a hammer or cutting with a saw. The edges of the resulting pieces may be chipped or faceted to increase the [[refraction]] and [[Specular reflection|reflection]] effects.
The pieces are laid out to a design, similar to traditional [[stained-glass]] work. The pieces are laid on a bed of sand, bounded by a wooden casting frame. A matrix material, sand and cement or epoxy resin, is poured between the glass pieces and allowed to dry, typically requiring 24 hours to harden. The visible glass faces are then cleaned and the resulting solid panel can be relocated, embedded or hung as required.
The use of thicker glass produces deeper colour effects than traditional [[lead]] [[came]] stained-glass, especially when illuminated by bright natural or artificial light.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vitraildutemple.free.fr/realisations/dalle.html |title= La dalle de verre |language=french |accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://osvaldsstainedglass.com/portfolio/dalle-de-verre-technique/| title=Dalle de Verre Technique |accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref>
The technique achieved prominence in the stained glass literature of the 1950s and 1960s.<ref name="Bubnash">{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.columbia.edu/files/gsapp/imceshared/lcl2127/Lacey_Bubnash_-_Thesis_Abstract.pdf |first=Lacey |last=Bubnash |work=Thesis Abstract |title=Dalle de Verre / Faceted Glass: New Approaches to a Modern Material |publisher=[[Columbia Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation|School of Architecture]], [[Columbia University]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510140934/http://www.arch.columbia.edu/files/gsapp/imceshared/lcl2127/Lacey_Bubnash_-_Thesis_Abstract.pdf |archivedate=2014-05-10 |df= }}</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Vitrail rocella i.jpg|Dalle de verre by Carlo Roccella Studio File:Vitrail roccella b.jpg|Dalle de verre by Carlo Roccella Studio File:Vitro buckfast.jpg| Dalle de verre at Buckstead Abbey, Dom Charles Norris </gallery>
==Problems and conservation== The resulting works may be subject to structural problems over time and, just like more traditional stained glass works, pose challenges to conservators and restorers.<ref name="Bubnash"/>
==Dalle de verre in the UK== Dalle de verre was brought to the UK by Pierre Fourmaintraux who joined [[James Powell and Sons]] (later Whitefriars Glass Studio) in 1956 and trained [[Dom Charles Norris]] in the technique. Norris was a Dominican Friar who went on to become arguably the most prolific British proponent of dalle de verre. His work is incorporated in several Modernist listed Catholic churches.

{{About|art technique|woman's fashion|d√©colletage}} '''D√©collage''', in [[art]], is the opposite of [[collage]]; instead of an image being built up of all or parts of existing images, it is created by cutting, tearing away or otherwise removing, pieces of an original image.<ref name="ArtLex">[http://www.artlex.com/ See D-De] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050424084418/http://www.artlex.com/ |date=2005-04-24 }}, ArtLex Art Dictionary. Retrieved 2007-10-17.</ref> The French word "d√©collage" translates into English literally as "take-off" or "to become unglued" or "to become unstuck". Examples of d√©collage include [[Surrealist techniques|etr√©cissements]] and [[cut-up technique]]. A similar technique is the ''lacerated poster'', a poster in which one has been placed over another or others, and the top poster or posters have been ripped, revealing to a greater or lesser degree the poster or posters underneath.
==Practitioners of d√©collage== An important practitioner of d√©collage was [[Wolf Vostell]]. Wolf Vostell noticed the word "d√©collage" in [[Le Figaro]] on 6 September 1954, where it was used to describe the simultaneous take-off and crash of an aeroplane. He appropriated the term to signify an aesthetic philosophy, applied also to the creation of live performances, Vostell‚Äôs working concept of d√©collage, was the D√©-coll/age and begun in 1954, is as a visual force that breaks down outworn values and replaces them with thinking as a function distanced from [[Media (communication)|media]]. He also called his [[Happening]]s D√©-coll/age-Happening.<ref>[http://www.kulturstiftung.de/publikationen/arsprototo/ausgaben/3-2013/mediale-wanderungen/ Wolf Vostell, D√©-coll/age-Happening]</ref><ref>''Beuys Brock Vostell. Aktion Demonstration Partizipation 1949-1983.''. ZKM-Zentrum f√ºr Kunst und Medientechnologie, Hatje Cantz, Karlsruhe, 2014, {{ISBN|978-3-7757-3864-4}}.</ref><ref>[http://www.hatjecantz.de/beuys-brock-vostell-6226-0.html Beuys Brock Vostell]</ref>
The most celebrated artists of the d√©collage technique in France, especially of the lacerated poster, are [[Fran√ßois Dufrene]], [[Jacques Villegl√©]], [[Mimmo Rotella]] and [[Raymond Hains]].<ref>Patrick Straram, "La veuve blanche et noire un peu d√©tourn√©e" (Paris Sens & Tonka, 2006), 21‚Äì22, 81‚Äì82; "Figures de la n√©gation" ([[Saint-Etienne M√©tropole: Mus√©e d'Art Moderne]], 2004), 78‚Äì80.</ref> Raymond Hains used the lacerated poster as an artistic intervention that sought to critique the newly emerged advertising technique of large-scale advertisements. In effect his decollage destroys the [[advertisement]], but leaves its remnants on view for the public to contemplate. Often these artists worked collaboratively and it was their intention to present their artworks in the city of Paris anonymously. These four artists were part of a larger group in the 1960s called [[Nouveau R√©alisme]] (New realism), Paris' answer to the American [[Pop Art]] movement. This was a mostly Paris-based group (which included [[Yves Klein]] and [[Christo]] and was created with the help of critic [[Pierre Restany]]), although Rotella was Italian and moved back to Italy shortly after the group was formed. Some early practitioners sought to extract the defaced poster from its original context and to take it into areas of poetry, photography, or painting.
Lacerated posters are also closely related to [[Richard Genovese]]'s practice of excavations. Contemporary artists employing similar d√©collage techniques are [[Mark Bradford]], Michael Viviani and [[Brian Dettmer]], who employs a novel method of decollage by removing material from books, leaving behind select images and text to form sculptural collages. Also there is Fizz Fieldgrass, an English artist, who uses [[digital media|digitally]] enhanced photographic images, overlaid by duplication on either Japanese Conservation Grade or fine [[Paper Mulberry]], torn and rolled back to reveal other layers generating the three-dimensional image.
D√©collage is now commonly used in the French language in regard to aviation (as when an aeroplane lifts off the ground). More recently the term has been used in space flight; the web page for [[ESA]] indicates its use equivalent to "We have lift-off!" at a [[NASA]] launch center.
==D√©chirage== D√©chirage (from the French, d√©chirer: 'to tear') is an artistic style that distresses paper to create a three-dimensional patchwork. It is a form of d√©collage, taking the original image apart physically through incision, parting and peeling away. [[Romare Bearden]] (b. 1911 ‚Äì d. 1988) the African American collage artist used d√©chirage as an important element of his [[Abstract expressionism|abstract expressionist]] paintings.<ref>'Bearden as Abstract Expressionist' http://www.courses.vcu.edu/ENG-mam/bio3.htm Maalek Marshall, Virginia Commonwealth University webpages.</ref> The first public display of "Photographic" D√©chirage (the tearing of layers of digital photographs to create a distinctive three-dimensional image) was at the ''Art of Giving''<ref>[http://www.saatchionline.com/art/view/artist/162075/art/91318#comment-76575-91318 Sea-cloth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220105041/http://www.saatchiart.com/art/Collage-Sea-cloth/162075/91318/view|archivedate=2014-02-20}}</ref> exhibition at the [[Saatchi Gallery]] in 2010.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
It can be argued that the depliage is a form of d√©collage, as it is made by initially removing the staples from a staple-bound [[magazine]].
